CONJUGATES: tenures (n. pl.) | tenured (v. past/p.p.) | tenuring (v. pres. part.)
ETYMOLOGY: From Old French tenure (possession, holding), from Latin tenēre (to hold, keep).

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The status of holding a position or office permanently, especially one giving job security and academic freedom to faculty members at a university, ensuring dismissal only for major cause.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 终身教职；永久任期（尤指大学教师享有的稳定职位，非重大过失不得解雇）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: After years of review, the committee finally granted her tenure.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 经过多年的审查，委员会最终授予了她终身教职。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The period or term during which a position or office is held.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: His tenure as the Chief Justice lasted for nearly two decades.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他担任首席大法官的任期持续了近二十年。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: To grant permanent job status to an employee, usually a university faculty member.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The department plans to tenure the two associate professors next year.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 该系计划明年授予这两名副教授终身职位。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The conditions or terms under which land or property is held.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 土地或财产的保有方式或条件（尤指封建时代的土地保有权）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The old lease specified the exact form of land tenure.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 旧租约详细规定了土地保有权的准确形式。
